review.title: Pearl's Calculus of Intervention Is Complete
review.abstract: This paper is concerned with graphical criteria that can be used to solve the problem of identifying casual effects from nonexperimental data in a causal Bayesian network structure, i.e., a directed acyclic graph that represents causal relationships. We first review Pearl's work on this topic [Pearl, 1995], in which several useful graphical criteria are presented. Then we present a complete algorithm [Huang and Valtorta, 2006b] for the identifiability problem. By exploiting the completeness of this algorithm, we prove that the three basic do-calculus rules that Pearl presents are complete, in the sense that, if a causal effect is identifiable, there exists a sequence of applications of the rules of the do-calculus that transforms the causal effect formula into a formula that only includes observational quantities.

metadata.title: Pearl’s Calculus of Intervention Is Complete

sections.text: This paper deals with graphical criteria that can be used to solve the problem of identifying random effects from non-experimental data in a Bayesian causal network structure, i.e. a directed acyclic graph that represents causal relationships. We first review Pearl's work on this topic [Pearl, 1995], which presents several useful graphical criteria, and then present a complete algorithm [Huang and Valtorta, 2006b] for the identification problem. By using the completeness of this algorithm, we prove that the three basic do-calculus rules Pearl presents are complete in the sense that when a causal effect is identifiable, there exists a sequence of applications of the rules of the do-calculus that transform the formula of the causal effect into a formula that includes only observational quantities.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this essay, we prove that the do-calculus method of [Pearl, 1995] is complete, in the sense that when a causal effect is discernible, there is a sequence of applications of the rules of the do-calculus method that transforms the formula of the causal effect into one that only includes observable quantities. In fact, the constructive evidence in the fifth section not only shows us that these rules are complete, but also provides formal recursive algorithms to perform calculations with rules 2 and 3 when we need problem 1 or 2. Together with the algorithm we have outlined in section four, we get a formal procedure to solve the identification problem and calculate causal effects using the graphical rules 2 and 3.
